entry.title: Parable of the onion
entry.content:
Let talk about something spiritual. While browsing Reddit the other day I found a very interesting story that I would definitely like to share. This story is called the Parable of the Onion.

The Story

Once upon a time there was an old woman who had died and found herself in hell. She complained to Satan that her assignment to the netherworld was a mistake.

Satan told her, “You’ve been a greedy, selfish woman all your life. Surely, this is where you belong.”

The woman thought a long time, trying to recollect some shred of altruism in her life. After several minutes she exclaimed, “Aha! I did a good deed once! I gave an onion to a beggar.”

Satan replied, “Oh, yes. That is right. You pulled an onion out of the ground in your yard and handed it (bulb, stalk, and all) to a beggar at the fence.”

At that very moment, God’s hand descended into hell, holding the onion out for the woman to grasp. Holding onto the onion with both hands, the woman found herself miraculously being pulled up and out of hell.

As she rose, to the woman’s horror, dozens of people began to grasp at her legs and ankles, and as they were pulled up along with her, yet more people grasped onto the lower-most people’s own legs and ankles, until it seemed that the bowels of hell clung like an endless chain from a single woman’s body and the onion to which she clung.

Though there was great weight tethered to the onion, the connection remained secure and God’s hand continued to lift everyone up out of hell. Remarkably, the onion held; it did not fray.

More and more people who had previously been doomed for eternity found themselves slowly, miraculously, being raised from hell by way of the woman’s firm grasp on the onion. There were soon thousands, and after several minutes millions of people hanging from the onion.

Yet the onion held fast.

Halfway to heaven, which is a long distance up from hell, the woman looked down at the vast human chain following her.

She was angry and resentful that these people – who may have done even less good in their lives than herself – should be so easily redeemed by virtue of simply clinging to her spindly old legs. She was also afraid, and so exclaimed in a great shout, “If all of you grab on to me like this, the onion will surely break and I will not get to heaven!”

So, resolving not to allow anyone to harm her chances for redemption, the woman began to kick and smash the people hanging from her legs and ankles and toes. One by one as she struck them they fell, with each loss of a handhold causing tens of thousands of people to plunge back into hell.

But with each kick – though the physical load grew lighter – the onion began to fray. And as the onion frayed, the woman, in her anger and haste, began to kick more ferociously still, thinking that it was the weight of hell’s denizens – and not her anger and selfishness – that tore at the onion.

She kicked until but one person remained clinging to her left big toe, with yet another endless chain of people dangling from him. Millions of people hung from that precious, single toe. Still, the onion held though it was severely frayed. But the woman couldn’t bear the risk of losing her only chance to join God in heaven, so she kicked at the last remaining person; and as the person lost his grip, the onion snapped, and the selfish old woman – from a great height, having made it almost all the way to heaven; fell back into hell.

What do I think

Very short and beautiful one, I really like these little story with good message behind them. From my perspective Old Lady represent any random person from our society. Most of us just want to help
overselves, there is little thought about others. Most of us are ready to take away someone else’s hard work.

Onion represent the spiritual connection with higher plane. Many wants to be more spiritual in their life but they forget to do basic good deeds. They will go to Yoga class or Vipasana retreats to be more spiritual but will not help someone in need. I think definition of being spiritual has foiled in our modern society.

Source

As a disclaimer I have taken this story from Reddit comment section. But I will surely share the original source here.

In last post we learn how to setup a blog using Hexo. Now we will see how we can configure it further.

Just like any blogging platform we need hexo to create posts for us. Lets learn how to do that.

Creating Post

Once your blog is ready creating a post is really easy. You can run this command to create an empty post.

This will create a new post hello-world.md under /source/_posts folder.

Internally this command pick the template from /scaffolds, so you can add any number of templates there. So when we say create post it look for /scaffolds/post.md and copy it inside /source/_posts folder.

You can edit the post now, there are various option available for post page. But its still not published.

Generating Static Files

Your post is created but its still not visible on frontend. This is because we need to generate static files for it. Run the command below to generate them.

This will read your sources directory and generate posts in form of html files.

Deploying to Git

You can set hexo to deploy your blog to git or heroku when you need. This will require some configuration. Lets see how we can connect our Hexo blog to Github.

You will need to open _config.yml configuration file. Then find deploy setting. It can be empty. You need to configure it, so it will look something like this.

As you can see, we can even specify which branch you want to deploy. Once you have configured the settings properly, you can run command below to deploy your blog.

With this we have learned how to use Hexo as a blog. We have just covered basic setup and there is always more to learn. You can find more useful stuff at Hexo.io

entry.title: How to use Hexo as your blog ? (Part 1)
entry.content:
Recently I wanted to change my Github page to a blog. I was looking for some automated options, where I don’t have to build yet another blog. But I wanted it to be simple and minimalistic.

Github do provide an option of Jekyll. It looks really cool but I am not much familiar with Ruby language yet. I wanted something that I could tweak easily.

So I started looking for something in Node realm. Then I found Hexo, its simple to setup and use. Its like Jekyll in JavaScript.

Let see how you can setup your first blog.

Installing and Creating

Hexo is available as a CLI by using npm. Lets install this package for global use.

Once Hexo CLI has been installed, command hexo will be available. Now its time to create a new blog. Its simple as this command.

Hexo will create a folder called my-blaggg. New version of Hexo does npm install itself. Basically your blog is now ready for creating new posts.

Configure

Before starting we should at least change name of our blog. This can be done by modifying a file called _config.yml, you can find it under my-blaag folder.

It offers various option to configure but we will start with basics. We need to change the name and timezone for now.

Timezone can be any valid moment.js timezone string. Whole list of timezone is available here.

Installing a theme

Hexo supports plugins and themes. I myself didn’t like the stock theme very much. Here are various themes that Hexo community provides.

After you have selected any theme you have to clone it under your themes folder. Under your blog directory you can run this command.

This will clone my blog’s current theme to your local blog. Now you have to change config settings to use this new theme.

Under your blog’s (not your theme’s config) _config.yml you have to change the theme parameter to apollo.

Local development

Now you can view your blog by running this simple command.

This will serve the blog on localhost:4000, Open this url in your browser to checkout you new Hexo blog.

Next

We will learn how to create posts and pages. We will also setup Hexo git deployment tool.
